newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan says Israel blocking joint Aqaba airport.
newsitem.headline: Jordan says Israel blocking joint Aqaba airport.

text.p: Jordan accused Israel on Saturday of derailing a plan to operate a joint airport near its Red Sea port of Aqaba by raising security concerns which infringe its sovereignty.

Deputy Prime Minister Jawad Anani said Israel came up with "new unaceptable conditions" after top aviation officials reached an initial agreement this week on diverting international flights to Aqaba from the nearby Israeli beach resort of Eilat.
"When we started to discuss arrangements, they came to us with new conditions and new matters which we feel we cannot accept," Anani told reporters.
The project to transfer flights from Eilat to Aqaba, just nine km (six miles) away, was the first major Israeli-Jordanian venture announced after the 1994 Jordan-Israel peace treaty.

The accord involves expanding Aqaba airport's facilities to eventually divert all of Eilat's international flights, an estimated 150 flights a month, leaving the congested airport to domestic Israeli traffic. A test stage was originally scheduled before the end of August.

But Anani, without elaborating, said most of the new Israeli conditions which surfaced after concluding most of the technical operational arrangments were security-related and infringed Jordan's sovereignty.
"We insist that Jordan is a country which respects itself and its sovereignty and cannot accept that anyone undertakes a role on its behalf of it in its territory," Anani said.
Officials said he was referring to Israeli demands to built a temporary passenger terminal alongside the existing one on Jordanian territory, with Israel maintaining full security control.
The airport project has been stalled for months but received fresh impetus at a summit in May between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Jordan's King Hussein.
